Larry North heads south to new digs in Preston Center Filed under Business at Get Daily Dallas News Headlines Sign Up Get Unlimited Digital Access Your first month is less than a dollar. $0.99 for first 4 weeks Subscribe Now 
Larry North is back in the Park Cities where he started. 
Last week, when Dallas' best-known fitness celebrity moved his Larry North Fitness-Preston Royal a couple of miles south to Preston Center, he made good on a vow he'd made to himself nearly a decade ago. 
In 2009, Ray Washburne bought Highland Park Village from the Henry S. Miller Jr. family. The new landlord had plans for the space that had been North's flagship gym for nearly 20 years. So North got the boot. 
North sued and settled. But he had to move out. 
But it was more than a lease that he lost. North also left his heart behind. 
His original gym, opened when North was just 28, created his fitness persona. It spawned fitness clubs, best-selling books, speaking gigs, TV appearances, licenses, sponsorships and the Great North American Slimdown , a 1990s infomercial phenomenon that brought in $150 million in revenue during the eight years it aired around the world. 
"I was deeply, emotionally attached to that club," says North, who turns 56 on Thursday. "When I had to take the last piece of equipment out of it, I was the only one in there, I bawled like a baby. I remember walking down those steps for the last time, and my self-talk is: 'I'll be back. And I'll come back better and stronger.' 
"It took eight years, but I am back in the 'hood." Brandi Farris group fitness director leads a Zumba class. (Nathan Hunsinger/The Dallas Morning News) Staff Photographer 
And he's returned in millennial style, hoping to attract a younger clientele with his not-your-mother's gym. 
"We're making this into a hip, sexy, eclectic club," says North, surveying the work that's not quite finished yet. "My Highland Park club meets the 21st century." 
His 15,000-square-foot gym is just down from the popular Hopdoddy's on Luther Lane. Moody Family YMCA had been using it while its new facility was being built. 
Perfunctory was transformed into edgy by Dallas architect Tyler Duncan, known for his work at restaurants such as The Porch, Avenu Lounge, Bombshell's Restaurant and Bar, and Mi Cocina. 
"Most gyms have no character," Duncan says. "They're a sea of equipment, and they're very vanilla -- nothing that creates conversation." 
Duncan's favorite element is a large metal-and-glass garage door that serves as a noise barrier when Zumba and other classes are in session but opens for extra training room when they're not. 
Then there's the mood lighting. 
"Most gyms are flooded with harsh light, which makes your skin color look horrible," Duncan says. "Warm lighting warms up skin tones so that when people look at themselves in the mirror, they feel good about themselves." Tyler Duncan designed Larry North's new gym with millennials in mind. (Nathan Hunsinger/The Dallas Morning News) 
And it makes for better selfies -- also a design desire. 
So does a massive graffiti wall that creates an identifiable backdrop for social media posts. 
"That is a great way to capture free advertising," Duncan says. "People who've been here will say, 'Oh, I know where that is. They're at Larry North because they have that sick graffiti wall.' It'll spark some interest." 'Hustle wall' 
North loves the "hustle wall" of motivational sayings that honors Dallas billionaire Darwin Deason, North's mentor, buddy, trainee and financial backer for decades. It features the motto of the founder of Affiliated Computer Services: "Good things come to those who are patient -- normally the leftovers from those who hustle." 
Deason is thrilled with the tribute. "Larry's a lovable prince of a guy," he says. "Any help I can give Larry, I will. Larry's become like my third son." 
And North considers Deason the father he wished he'd had. 
"My dad was a degenerate and compulsive gambler, Brooklyn mobster type in New York," North says. "He was into bookies, shylocks, loan sharks, family, friends, whoever he could get money from. So we moved around because he was constantly on the lam. He blew every dime we ever had." 
By the time Larry turned 15, he, his mom and his decade-younger twin brothers had been uprooted more than a dozen times in New York, Las Vegas and Los Angeles neighborhoods. 
In 1978, Larry and his mother decided to pack up the family and flee to Houston. Since Texas didn't have legal gambling, they figured that even if even Larry's father found them, he wouldn't stick around. 
But they never made it -- their car's engine blew up at Spring Valley Road and North Central Expressway. 
The family moved into the nearby Continental Inn, an $18-a-night motel. 
"There was a Pancho's [all-you-could-eat Mexican restaurant] next door, so my mom could feed the family for about five bucks since kids ate free," he says. "We also went to NorthPark, which had 10-cent hot dog specials as part of its opening. 
"That's how she fed us until she was able to get a job and we got a small apartment in Richardson. She still lives in Richardson today." Bus to Doug's 
Larry helped his mom while going to J.J. Pearce High School. 
At 16, he got a janitorial job and a free membership at Doug's Gym, riding the bus to and from Richardson to downtown. 
He became one of Dallas' first personal trainers in 1981. 
"I'm bouncing [at a nightclub] on weekends. I'm selling shoes at Neiman Marcus. I'm training people at 6 in the morning, and going to school at Richland [College]," he says. "An 80-hour workweek would have been part-time employment for me. But I liked it because I was generating revenue and I liked people." A photograph of Larry North is used to paint his likeness on a mural. (Nathan Hunsinger/The Dallas Morning News) 
A pumped-up bodybuilder selling ladies' shoes at Neiman's? 
"I read every single Vogue, Cosmopolitan, Bazaar magazine cover to cover," he says. "I knew what colors were in style, what purses were in style. I've always been a student of whatever I did." 
In 1985, the exclusive San Simeon nightclub lured him back into the bouncing business. He made $200 a night in cash, with hundreds more in tips. "It was best decision I ever made, not because of the money but because all the people in Highland Park went to that club." 
That same year, North waltzed into the office of the program director at KLIF-AM (570) and said he wanted to do a fitness radio show. 
Two weeks later, he had one. 
Thirty years later, North is still on air at KRLD-AM (1080) with lucrative sponsorships from BioTE Medical hormone pellets and ViaScan, which provides body scans. Northwest Highway barrier 
Everywhere he worked, North told people he was going to own his own gym someday. 
Now he has four -- in Dallas at Preston Center and Cityplace, in Fort Worth and in Westlake. North says they're profitable and will bring in about $4.5 million this year. 
North is the majority owner but has major investment backing from Deason and Brint Ryan, CEO of Ryan LLC. Chris Gallagher, the company's president, and vice president Jimmy Makofske hold smaller stakes. 
"Larry is alway in motion, high-energy, very enthusiastic and always looking to improve the business," says Gallagher, who started working for North nearly 24 years ago. "The worst thing is you gotta keep up with him. But that's good because in our business, you've got to move fast." 
North needs 1,000 members to turn a profit at Preston Center. That won't be a stretch, he says, if he can keep the 600-member base from the old location and re-engage the Park Cities set. 
When he lost his lease at Highland Park Village, he unsuccessfully tried to get its members to drive a few minutes north. 
"I believe that if you live in the Park Cities, your car has a governor on it that stalls it if you go past Northwest Highway," North says. 
Stacey Fikes has just finished a weight workout. The 29-year-old thinks Preston Center will be more attractive to her fellow millennials than Preston Hollow was. 
"There are a lot of apartment buildings going up," she says. "My friends and I go to a lot of places around here to grab something to eat and drink." 
She even moved to a new apartment to be closer to the gym. "I'm pretty attached to my trainer," she says. "Where he goes, I go." 
North, who still works out diligently, says his sense of purpose has changed now that he's in his 50s. 
"As younger person, I was in this business to help people look good in a bikini or have a harder body or build up self-esteem," he says. "Now I have a stronger mission for healthy living, not just living for the sake of a slimmer waistline. 
"I enjoy it more. It's a more fun message. And millennials, surprisingly, resonate with it." 
And while North still smarts from what happened to him at Highland Park Village, he says it made him smarter. 
"It forced to me to pivot and make adjustments," he says. "If it hadn't happened, I would have been swallowed up by these bigger clubs and these boutique clubs coming into and flooding the market. 
"The one thing my competition can't be is me." 
#### Larry North Fitness 
Founded: April 1, 1989 
Ownership: Larry North holds the majority stake. Major shareholders are Dallas businessmen Brint Ryan and Darwin Deason. Company president Chris Gallagher and vice president Jimmy Makofske own smaller stakes. Annual revenue: $4.5 million Locations: Cityplace, Preston Center, Fort Worth and Westlake 
Total membership: Nearly 5,000 
Title: CEO, Majority owner, Larry North Fitness LLC 
Age: 55 
Resides: Far North Dallas 
Education: J.J. Pearce High School, 1979; attended Richland College and the University of North Texas 
Per sonal: Married to Brenda Stone for 11 years. They have a daughter, 27, and a son, 24. 
SOURCE: Larry North
